column1: Gore: If you gave me only one wish for the next 50 years  I could pick a vaccine, which is something I love This is the wish I would pick. We're in a wonderful situation with electricity in the rich world, he says.

Bill Gates: To actually do the software, buy the supercomputer, hire all the great scientists, that's only tens of millions. The tough thing is building the pilot reactor  finding the several billion, finding the regulator, the location that will actually build the first one of these.

The nuclear power plant would be its own waste disposal solution. The waste would sit there and burn for 60 years, and then it's done. The company is talking to different people around the world about the possibilities. It's an important advance, but it's like a fast reactor, and a lot of countries have built them.

TerraPower is working on a plan to emit CO2 into the atmosphere. The project could have a huge impact on the environment. TerraPower is hoping to have a pilot plant in place by 2015. The company is working with a number of other companies on the project.

BG: The main problem we have here  it's kind of like with AIDS: you make the mistake now, and you pay for it a lot later. BG: If you can make it economic, and meet the CO2 constraints, then the skeptics say, OK, I don't care that it doesn't put out CO2

Climate change expert: We should try more things that have a potential to be far less expensive If the tradeoff you get into is, Let's make energy super expensive, then the rich can afford that, he says. The disaster is for that two billion

The world puts out 26 billion tons of carbon dioxide every year. For each American, it's about 20 tons, for people in poor countries it's less than one ton. We have to go from rapidly rising to falling, and falling all the way to zero

Every year, this number, on average, is going to go up, and so, overall, that will more than double the services delivered per person. Some individual services even bring it down by 90 percent. But for these first three factors now, we've gone from 26 billion to, at best, maybe 13 billion tons.

Climate change means many years, crops won't grow, he says. So we need energy miracles, he adds. This is a case where we actually have to drive at full speed and get a miracle in a pretty tight timeline, he writes. We don't have a deadline where you have to get the miracle by a certain date

CNN's John Sutter looks at ways to reduce CO2 emissions. Sutter: We need solutions, either one or several, that have unbelievable scale and unbelievable reliability I decided that releasing fireflies would be my contribution to the environment here this year, Sutter says.

Renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar, don't require fuel. But the density of energy gathered in these technologies is dramatically less than a power plant. These are intermittent sources, so the climate changes will be terrible for them. Nuclear power also has three big problems.

TED Talk: If you could pick just one thing to lower the price of to reduce poverty, by far you would pick energy. All the batteries we make now could store less than 10 minutes of all the energy. We need lots of companies working on this  hundreds of people.

Nathan Myhrvold and I are backing a company that, perhaps surprisingly, is actually taking the nuclear approach. The idea of TerraPower is that, instead of burning a part of uranium  the one percent, which is the U235  we decided, Let's burn the 99 percent

CNN's John Defterios looks at how the world can reduce CO2 emissions. He says the first step is to get to an 80 percent reduction in emissions. Defterio: The second step is that we have to make sure that we are using this technology

CNN's John Sutter talks about the power of the human spirit. Sutter: All you really need is one person to show you the epiphany of your own power Sutter says he's changed because of the people who have opened his eyes.

The God Who Only Knows Four Words is a poem by Persian poet Hafiz. The God who only knows four words and keeps repeating them, saying, 'Come, dance with me'  is a powerful piece of poetry. The words whole and wholesome refer to a person's spirit.

Aimee O'Mara says her childhood doctor at the A.I. duPont Institute opened doors for her as a child. She says he told her she was such a strong and powerful little girl, I think you're going to break one of those bands O' Mara: It's not just about the words, it's what we believe about people when we name them.

Adversity isn't an obstacle that we need to get around in order to resume living our life We are marked, of course, by a challenge, whether physically, emotionally or both Our responsibility is not simply shielding those we care for from adversity, but preparing them

We do a disservice to our kids when we make them feel that they're not equipped to adapt. We need to see through the pathology and into the range of human capability. And, perhaps, until we're tested, we don't know what we're made of.

Aimee Mullins: We can reimagine adversity as something more than just tough times. Adversity is just change that we haven't adapted ourselves to yet, Mullins says. Anthropologists tell us that the one thing we as humans have always required of our community members is to be of use.

I have no idea who he is. I don't remember meeting him, she says of the man who delivered her from the womb. He said he had been making a difference in my life since I was a little girl, she recalls. It's very difficult to think straight

Kahneman: Money does not buy you experiential happiness, but lack of money certainly buys you misery The more money you earn, the more satisfied you are. That does not hold for emotions, he says. Kahneman: If people took seriously that finding, it seems to turn upside down everything we believe about.

Kahneman: People are recognizing that they ought to be thinking of happiness when they think of public policy This is going to influence policy, I think, in years to come, he says. There's just no way of getting it right, he adds.

There are two selves: an experiencing self and a remembering self. The remembering self is the one that keeps score, and maintains the story of our life. Getting confused between the two is part of the mess about the notion of happiness, he says.

Researchers asked patients to report on their pain every 60 seconds. One patient had a much worse memory of the colonoscopy than the other. The one that is worse is the one where pain was at its peak at the very end; it's a bad story. There is a huge wave of interest in happiness, among researchers

Psychologist David Frum: What defines a story? Changes, significant moments and endings Frum says most of the moments of our life are ignored by the remembering self. Most of them don't leave a trace, he says. They are lost forever

The biggest difference between them is in the handling of time. Time is actually the critical variable that distinguishes a remembering self from an experiencing self. This applies to laypeople thinking about their own happiness, and it applies to scholars thinking about happiness, because it turns out we're just as messed up as anybody else.

How much do we consume our memories? That is one of the explanations that is given for the dominance of the remembering self. Why do we pick the vacations we do is a problem that confronts us with a choice between the two selves. There are really two concepts of happiness that we can apply.

Happiness is not about how happily a person lives. It is about how satisfied or pleased the person is when that person thinks about her life. The distinction between the happiness of the experiencing self and the satisfaction of the remembering self has been recognized in recent years.

Happiness is mainly being satisfied with people that we like, spending time with people we like. We know that money is very important, goals are very important. The bottom line of what I've said here is that we really should not think of happiness as a substitute for wellbeing. It is a completely different notion.

With Pivot, you can drill into a decade. You can jump right into a specific issue. You get the idea that when you navigate over information this way, you're not searching. You're doing something that's actually a little bit different. It changes the way information can be used.

CNN's John Sutter shows how to use information to see trends that would otherwise be invisible. Sutter: The whole of the data in which we consume is greater that the sum of the parts What we're done here is we've taken every single Wikipedia page and we reduced it down to a little summary

Pivot is an app that lets users zoom in and out of web pages. It also lets users see their entire browsing history in one place. The idea is that the web can be used to reveal hidden patterns in data. It could also help people extract information from data.

CNN's John Sutter uses a new tool to look at the causes of death in the U.S. Sutter says the data shows that the most common cause of death is death by natural causes. He says the new tool can be used to help people understand the cause of their own deaths.

As a child, I was always absorbed in a book, science fiction book, which took my mind to other worlds. So, filmmaking was the way to put pictures and stories together, and that made sense. I still, to this day, stand in absolute awe of what I see when I make these dives.

With The Abyss, I was putting together my love of underwater and diving with filmmaking. I witnessed something amazing, which is that the audience, the global audience, was mesmerized by this apparent magic. With Terminator 2, we created the liquid metal dude in that film. And it did, and we created magic again.

Avatar was meant to push the envelope of visual effects, of CG effects, beyond, with realistic human emotive characters generated in CG, he says. But the envelope pushed back, and he shelved it and made a movie about a big ship that sinks. Secretly, what he wanted to do was I wanted to dive to the real wreck of Titanic, he adds.

After the success of Titanic, he said, OK, I'm going to go be a fulltime explorer for a while I was a real science geek, he says. It was all about trying to understand the world, understand the limits of possibility

It was the most surreal kind of deja vu experience I've ever had, he says. When I say, I'm operating it, my mind is in the vehicle It may be a little bit of a glimpse as to what might be happening some decades out

I learned a lot about science, says Jacques Cousteau. I didn't really learn about leadership until I did these expeditions No fame, no glory, no money. What are you doing? You're doing it for the task itself, he says.

Avatar was tremendously exciting. Tremendously challenging. And we became a family, over a fourandhalf year period It completely changed how I do movies. It was more of a fundamental way of doing business, the process itself

CNN's John Defterios talks to CNN iReport about his new documentary, Fish in the Sea Defterio: For better or for worse, aquaculture, fish farming, is going to be a part of our future Failure is an option, but fear is not, he says.

CNN's John Sutter looks at the environmental benefits of fish farms. Sutter: Fish farms pollute, and they're inefficient. He says there's a better way: Farms that restore instead of deplete. If that's the future of good food, it's going to be delicious, Sutter says.

I've known a lot of fish in my life. I've loved only two. I was lying in bed, and I thought: What the hell is a sustainable protein? We're basically a world unto ourselves. That feed conversion ratio? 2.5 to one, he said.

There's just too much chicken in the world, he says. I swear to God, after that conversation, the fish tasted like chicken It was a beautiful fish: flavorful, textured, meaty, a bestseller on the menu

CNN's John Sutter tries a different kind of fish for the first time. This time, the fish is from a farm in southern Spain. The fish was overcooked, but it was still delicious, Sutter says. Sutter: Who can make a fish taste good after it's been overcooked? I can't, but this guy can.

Until the 1980s, the farm was in the hands of the Argentinians. In 1982, a Spanish company with an environmental conscience purchased the land. They reversed the flow of water. Instead of pushing water out, they used the channels to pull water back in.

Miguel is like three parts Charles Darwin and one part Crocodile Dundee. Miguel spent the better part of his career in the Mikumi National Park in Africa. Miguel is an expert in relationships. He is also an expert on rare birds and algaes and strange aquatic plants.

The farm has 600,000 birds on it, more than 250 different species. The system is so healthy, it's totally selfrenewing. The plant biomass, the phytoplankton, the zooplankston, is what feeds the fish. The fish are eating what they'd be eating in the wild.
The farm is not only a fish farm, but also a bird sanctuary. The flamingos eat the shrimp. The shrimp eat the phytoplankton. So the pinker the belly, the better the system, the owner says.

CNN's John Sutter talks to Miguel, owner of a fish farm in southern Spain. Miguel: The skin acts like a sponge. It's the last defense before anything enters the body. It evolved to soak up impurities Sutter: Our water has no impurities.

The world needs a radically new conception of agriculture, he says. One billion people will go hungry today, he adds. The food system has determined the logic of our food system for the last 50 years. How are you going to feed the world? Can I be honest? I don't love that question

An illusionist shows off a trick he uses to teach children about deception. The trick involves holding a knife in your hand and shifting your finger. The illusionist says the trick is very simple, but can teach you a great deal about deception by studying it.

The magician uses chicanery to trick people into believing he is giving them a placebo. He says the placebo effect is when something fake is believed in enough by somebody that it becomes something real The trick can be used to trick your friends and neighbors, too.

If you have capsules, they're more effective than tablets in any form. A colored capsule, that's yellow on one end and red on the other is better than a white capsule. One pill twice a day is not as good at three pills.

This is not a Hollywood special effect. This is really my flesh, he says. I'm going to show you what it looks like to go through the skin of a human being And then I'll show you the other side, he adds. And you'll see that it's not as bad as you think

This is a trick that's been in every children's magic book since at least the 1950s. I learned it myself from Cub Scout Magic in the 1970s. Something fake becomes something real because of someone's perception of it. I will be seeing you several times over the next few days. Thank you very much.

The Institute for the Future piloted the game with 1,700 players in 2007 and tracked them for the three years since. This is an amazing story and adventure for you to go on. Challenge yourself to see how you would survive, says the game's creator.

Superstruct is a game done with the World Bank Institute. If you complete the game, you will be certified as a Social Innovator, class of 2010. We had 8,000 people play that game for eight weeks. They came up with 500 creative solutions that you can go online, Google Superstruct, and see.

Jane McGonigal is a game designer and the creator of the popular Fortnite game. She says the game is a tool to help people solve reallife problems. McGonIGal: We can make any future we can imagine, and we can play any games we want

When we're in game worlds, I believe that many of us become the best version of ourselves. In real life, when we face failure, we often don't feel that way. We never have those feelings when we're playing games, they just don't exist in games. What about games makes it impossible to feel that we can't achieve everything?

There's no unemployment in World of Warcraft; no sitting around, wringing your hands  there's always something specific and important to be done. There are also tons of collaborators. Everywhere you go, hundreds of thousands of people ready to work with you to achieve your epic mission.

The average young person today in a country with a strong gamer culture will have spent 10,000 hours playing online games by the age of 21. For children in the United States, 10,080 hours is the exact amount of time you will spend in school, from fifth grade to high school graduation.

500 million people in the world spend at least an hour a day playing online games. The game industry is developing consoles that are lowenergy and that work with the wireless phone networks. They expect one billion more gamers in the next decade. It will bring us up to 1.5 billion gamers.

The average World of Warcraft gamer plays for 22 hours a week  kind of a halftime job. Gamers love to be attached to aweinspiring missions to human planetaryscale stories. We know that we are optimized as human beings, to do hard and meaningful work. And gamers are willing to work hard all the time.

We're witnessing what amounts to no less than a mass exodus to virtual worlds and online game environments We have to start making the real world work more like a game I take my inspiration from something that happened 2,500 years ago. It's not, by any means, an optimal situation

Before we had awesome game controllers, we had sheep's knuckles. Herodotus says that games, particularly dice games, were invented in the kingdom of Lydia, during a time of famine. On one day, everybody would eat, and the next day everybody would play games.

DNA evidence has shown that the Etruscans, who then led to the Roman Empire, actually share the same DNA as the ancient Lydians. Scientists have suggested that Herodotus' crazy story is actually true. They played dice games for 18 years, we've been playing Warcraft for 16 years.

We want to make the future a reality for people We don't want to predict the future, we want to help people get there It's not a game, it's a way of life I'm not trying to make people feel bad. I'm just trying to help them get to the future

I played the first movement of the Beethoven Violin Concerto. And as I played, I understood that there was a profound change occurring in Nathaniel's eyes Music allows him to take his thoughts and delusions and shape them through his imagination and his creativity

Bruno Giussani: Nathaniel Anthony Ayers, a double bassist, was homeless for 30 years. He says music brought him back into a family of musicians that understood him. Bruno: I will always make music with Nathaniel, whether we're at Walt Disney Concert Hall or Skid Row.

Vaccines, modern medicine, our ability to feed billions of people are triumphs of the scientific method, he says. We've never needed progress in science more than we need it right now, he adds. I think we can power this world with energy that doesn't also destroy it

Bob Greene: People wrap themselves in their beliefs, and they do it so tightly that you can't set them free. Greene: I didn't know what to do, so I just did what I do: I wrote a story and I moved on. You're not entitled to your own facts. Sorry, you're not.

We're at a point in this world where we don't have the same relationship to progress that we used to, he says. We've lost faith in institutions, in authority, and sometimes in science itself, and there's no reason we shouldn't have. Ask questions, demand proof, demand evidence, he adds.

We're now in an epidemic of fear like one I've never seen and hope never to see again When you get proof, you need to accept the proof, and we're not that good at doing that The United States is one of the only countries in the world where the vaccine rate for measles is going down
I don't want to go back, and it's not because I'm adventurous, he says. We need to learn it really soon, he adds. I'm not part of that crowd, but I have to say that I do understand it

Paul Offit developed a rotavirus vaccine with a bunch of other people. It'll save the lives of 400 to 500,000 kids in the developing world every year. He gets called at home because people like to tell him that they remember where his kids go to school.

We didn't have polio in this country yesterday, he says. That's the planet we live on. Don't pretend it isn't. Now, we love to wrap ourselves in lies. We love to do it. It doesn't matter how often we find out that they're useless. The data says it all the time. They darken your urine

I love Big Placebo. I'm totally with you. It's okay, you want to pay 28 billion dollars for dark urine? I think I understand, we hate Big Pharma. We hate Big Government. We don't trust the Man. And we shouldn't: Our health care system sucks

When you start down the road where belief and magic replace evidence and science, you end up in a place you don't want to be. Every single thing we eat, every grain of rice, every sprig of parsley, every Brussels sprout has been modified by man. It's an idiotic debate. It has to stop.

Vitamin A can help millions of people prolong their lives, he says. Some of it worked, and some of it didn't. We can do it in a more precise way, but there are risks, absolutely. It's true, we've got a huge food problem, but this isn't science, he adds.

In the next 50 years we're going to have to grow 70 percent more food than we do right now, 70 percent. We don't want to encourage people to eat that rotten stuff, like cassava for instance. It's not even an idea; it's a process. The idea that we should not allow science to do its job is very deadening.

This is about moving genes around. It's not about chemicals. This isn't about Rice Krispies, this is about keeping people alive, he says. We have to have these conversations and we have to think, but when we get in the time machine and we go ahead, we're going to be happy we do It's stuck in the present right now, but we have an amazing opportunity, he adds.

Among the worst are recent graduates of business school, who lie, cheat, get distracted and produce really lame structures. Among the best are kindergarteners, who produce the tallest structures. Peter Skillman introduced a design challenge called the marshmallow challenge.

Architects and engineers build the tallest freestanding structure out of 20 sticks of spaghetti, one yard of tape and a marshmallow. Thirtynine inches is the tallest structure I've seen. Architects and engineers understand triangles and selfreinforcing geometrical patterns.

The challenge was to build the tallest marshmallow in the shortest amount of time. The winner of the challenge received a $10,000 prize. The challenge was designed to teach students how to use digital tools to make better products. It was also a chance for students to test their own ideas of what a good design is.

Every project has its own marshmallow, doesn't it? The challenge provides a shared experience, a common language and a common stance to build the right prototype. And, though it seems really simple, it's actually pretty hard because it forces people to collaborate very quickly.
Bezos: I am witness to acts of generosity and kindness on a monumental scale I know what you're thinking, but I'm no hero, he says. I swear. I swear, he adds, I'm not a hero.

CNN's John Defterios is on a mission to make a difference in the lives of people in need. He is raising awareness about the need to help those who need it most. Defterio: Don't wait until you're in need to do something to help others.

The Congo is a land of extraordinary biodiversity and beauty. It is also the scene of a violent conflict that has claimed nearly as many lives as the First World War. Bonobos, like humans, love to play throughout their entire lives. They have frequent, promiscuous and bisexual sex to manage conflict.

Play is where we learn about the rules of the game. Play is not just child's games, it's a way of life. It's also a way for people to bond and learn from each other. Play can be very serious or very funny. It can also be very silly.

Fuku, a young female bonobo, is seen playing with water in the Congo jungle. Fuku says play is the key to our capacity to adapt to an increasingly challenging world. In times when it seems least appropriate to play, it might be the time when it is most urgent.

The Human Universal Load Carrier can carry 200 lbs. over varied terrain. Its flexible design allows for deep squats, crawls and highagility movements. Eythor Bender: We are ready with our partner to introduce this device, this new exoskeleton.

Amanda Boxtel was paralyzed after a freak summersault while downhill skiing. She has not been able to walk for 19 years until now. The eLEGS set has sensors in the crutches that send signals back to an onboard computer.

Berkeley Bionics is developing a new type of wheelchair called an exoskeleton. The technology is designed to help people with chronic back injuries. The company has already had 900 million impressions on its YouTube channel. It is not yet available in other countries or on TV.

Embrace Transparency is a new documentary about the power of big data. The film was funded by EMC, who bought the naming rights on eBay for $7,100. Embrace fear. Embrace risk. One big spoonful at a time, we have to embrace risk

Spurlock: I have spent the past few years putting myself into situations that are usually very difficult and at the same time somewhat dangerous The Greatest Movie Ever Sold is a film all about product placement, marketing and advertising, Spurlock says. I knew that someone would buy the naming rights, he says.

The Greatest Movie Ever Sold will be released on DVD and Bluray. The film is based on a true story about a man's journey to find out who he is and what he wants to do with the rest of his life. The movie will also be available to stream on YouTube.

Stuart Ruderfer: The responses mostly will be no I worked in a coal mine  dangerous, he says. We've got some places we can go, he adds. I was amazed. None of them wanted anything to do with this movie We look like a bunch of blithering idiots, Ruderfer says.

I spent 30 days eating nothing but this  fun in the beginning, little difficult in the middle, very dangerous in the end, says Sergey Brin. I filmed in war zones  difficult and dangerous. They wanted absolutely nothing to do with this project, he adds.

MS: Most of my career, I've been immersing myself into seemingly horrible situations for the whole goal of trying to examine societal issues in a way that make them engaging. MS: With this film, we wanted to tell the real story. The idea of understanding your brand is a universal problem.

Ban deodorant will be featured in a new movie, The Greatest Movie Ever Sold The brand is challenging Hollywood brands, says founder Karen Frank. Ban is bold, fresh and fights odor and wetness, Man says.

Gerry says he wants to talk to the people who are like him, the regular Joes. I like really nice clothes. I like a lot of black colors, he says. If Dan were a brand, he might be a classic convertible Mercedes Benz

Man 1: The brand that I am is, I would call it casual fly. Man 2: Part hippie, part yogi, part Brooklyn girl  I don't know. Man 3: I'm the pet guy. Man 4: My brand is FedEx because I deliver the goods. Man 5: Failed writeralcoholic brand.

I like things that are weird. I like weird things, says singersongwriter. It's like, who do I want to be? he asks. These are the people who shape the way I look at the world, he says of his friends and family.

CNN's Lindsay Zaltman asks Morgan Spurlock about his brand personality. Spurlock says his brand is a playful, mindful brand. He says some companies focus on one or the other instead of focusing on both. There was a whole lot of crazy going on in there, he says of his TED Talk naming contest.

Chris Anderson's new film is about neuromarketing. Anderson: We had 500plus companies who were up and down companies saying, no They wanted nothing to do with this film, mainly because they would have no control, Anderson says. We did get 17 brand partners who were willing to relinquish that control
CNN's John Sutter talks about his work with a new type of laser. The laser can be used to project images onto a wall. Sutter: It's a new way to communicate with the public. It's a very exciting time

The EyeWriter is a device that allows people to draw and communicate using only their eyes. The EyeWriter was created by a group of people who spent two weeks programming the device. The device is free to build and to download, and you can download the software for free.

TEMPT is now completely paralyzed. He only has use of his eyes. We kicked his bed so that he could see out. And we set up a projector on a wall out in the parking lot outside of his hospital. And he drew again for the first time, in front of his family and friends.

In April of this year, at the Geffen MOCA in downtown Los Angeles, there's going to be an exhibition called Art of the Streets Time magazine honored us as one of the top 50 inventions of 2010. If you see something that's not possible, make it possible

CNN's John Sutter talks about the role of evolution in human evolution. Sutter: For better or worse, and sooner than you may think, these choices will be up to us Is it just about the past, or is it about the future? he asks. How would you like to be better than you are?

We have been here for about 130,000 years. We branch off of a common ancestor to modern chimpanzees about six or eight million years ago. We carry in our gut more bacteria than there are cells in the rest of our body. The gut is a wonderfully hospitable environment for those bacteria.

The Big Bang took place 14 billion years ago. The human species emerged in the last 130,000 years. In most of the existence of life in singlecelled organisms, each cell simply divides, and all of the genetic energy of that cell is carried on in both daughter cells. Sexual reproduction enters the picture.

I was trying to preserve the body. I wanted us to live long and healthy lives, he says. I don't want to achieve it through not dying. I want it through living well. I want to live as long as I can, he adds. That's what I want to do.

Evolution favors those creatures best adapted to their environment. At the bottom of the ocean, bacteria that are thermophilic and can survive at the steam vent heat that would otherwise produce, if fish were there, sousvide cooked fish.

The Human Genome Project started in 1990, and it took 13 years. It cost 2.7 billion dollars. Neoevolution is the new evolution that is guided and chosen by us as individuals in the choices that we will make.

In 2004, you could have a complete sequence of the human genome for 20,000 dollars. The same technology that has produced the human insulin in bacteria can make viruses that will not only protect you against themselves, but induce immunity against other viruses. An experimental vaccine against influenza has been grown in the cells of a tobacco plant.

Evolution has been a perennial topic here at the TED Conference, but I want to give you today one doctor's take on the subject. Why not have the quick wit of a Ken Jennings, especially if you can augment it with the next generation of the Watson machine? Why not live longer? These will be irresistible.

Antonelli: Our objects, our environment is starting to talk back to us It's almost as if every atom out there were becoming both a sensor and an actuator That is radically changing the interaction we have as humans with the environment out there

In 2006, Italy won the soccer World Cup, and then Zidane at the end, the headbutt. Now look at what happened that day just by monitoring activity happening on the network. You see the Colosseum in the middle, the river Tiber.

Researchers in Seattle used tags to track trash as it moves through the system. The tags were placed on items that people would throw away anyway. The results show that the tags can be used to track objects with much less energy. The project was funded by the U.S. Department of Energy.

The first project is something we did a couple of years ago in Zaragoza, Spain. It started with a question by the mayor of the city, who came to us saying that Spain and Southern Europe have a beautiful tradition of using water in public space.

The Digital Water Pavilion is made of water. There are no doors or windows, but when you approach it, it will open up to let you in. The roof also is covered with water. If there's a bit of wind, if you want to minimize splashing, you can lower the roof.

The Flyfire project is a 3D cloud of pixels that can move in space. The pixels are made of water, and then projections are made on them. The project was inspired by the idea of winning a Formula 1 race with a good driver and a good car.

We've been working with Roberto Bolle, one of today's top ballet dancers. We captured his movement in 3D in order to use it as an input for Flyfire. It's both 3D scanning in real time and motion capture. So you can reconstruct a whole movement.

For the first time, we can go from the digital world, from the selforganizing power of networks, to the physical one. This has been digitizing everything, knowledge, and making that accessible through the Internet. But tomorrow it can be, to tackle today's pressing challenges.

Amitai Bhatnagar: I get a lot of people asking me: What do you get for 10 billion pixels? So I'm going to try and show you what you really get for10 billion pixels. Amitai: You can zoom around very simply. You can go to the end of the corridor. Have fun.

CNN's John Sutter takes a tour of the MoMA in New York. Sutter: You see some fun stuff happening here. But then you really want to go deep. And so I started playing around, and I found something going on over here

The Power of Zoom lets you zoom in and out of Van Gogh's masterpieces. Collections lets you create your own museum of the artist's work. You can annotate the stuff, send it to your friends and really get a conversation going.

GoogleArtProject.com is a new online museum. The site features works by artists from around the world. The project was created to make art more accessible to the general public. It is available in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish and Dutch.

Physicists used to use quantum mechanics to describe small, tiny particles. But now they use it to describe the large, everyday objects around us. It didn't really sit well with my intuition, and maybe it's just because I don't play with particles very often

neurons are the information processing apparatus that those communities of cells built up. Atoms are injected into a vacuum chamber and a magnetic field draws them towards the center. Stress resilience is the active biological process that allows us to bounce back after stress. insufficient resilience can result in a psychiatric disorder, such as depression.

Depression and PTSD are chronic, often lifelong, clinical diseases. They also increase the risk of substance abuse, homelessness, heart disease, Alzheimer's, suicide. The global cost of depression alone is over three trillion dollars per year. This is the first time a drug has been shown to prevent the negative effects of stress.

The first vaccine was discovered in 1798, but it was only for smallpox. Now scientists have discovered drugs that could prevent depression and PTSD. The drugs work by increasing stress resilience, so let's call them resilience enhancers. They are a whole new class of drug that could have a huge impact.

Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle was first stated by German physicist Werner Heisenberg back in 1927. The uncertainty isn't a matter of measuring well or badly, but an inevitable result of combining particle and wave nature. Particles, by definition, exist in one place at any instant in time. Waves, on the other hand, are disturbances spread out in space.

The wavelength of a cat running from a physicist would be as small as an atom within that Solar System. That's far too small to detect, so we'll never see wave behavior from a cat. A tiny particle, like an electron, can show dramatic evidence of its dual nature.

An electron in a molecule isn't on just atom A or atom B, but A+ B. The electrons in a solid aren't bound to a particular atom but shared among all of them. Understanding how electrons are shared among atoms allows us to precisely control the properties of semiconductor materials, like silicon. Combining different semiconductors in the right way allows to make transistors on a tiny scale.

The quantum phenomenon of superposition is a consequence of the dual particle and wave nature of everything. In order for an object to have a wavelength, it must extend over some region of space, which means it occupies many positions at the same time. Add up the numbers in each row, and you'll get successive powers of two. In a given row, treat each number as part of a decimal expansion. The numbers in the next diagonal are called the triangular numbers. If you add thousands of rows, you get a fractal known as Sierpinski's Triangle.

In the Western world, it's known as Pascal's Triangle after French mathematician Blaise Pascal. In China, it is known as Yang Hui's Triangle. It is a testament to the elegantly  interwoven fabric of mathematics. And it's still revealing fresh secrets to this day.

Pascal's Triangle looks like a neatly arranged stack of numbers, but it's actually a mathematical treasure trove. The coefficients,  or numbers in front of the variables, are the same as the numbers in that row of Pascal's Triangle. Age also affects  our memorymaking abilities.

The placebo effect is an unexplained phenomenon where drugs, treatments, and therapies that aren't supposed to have an effect, miraculously make people feel better. Placebos seem to be capable of causing measurable change in blood pressure, heart rate, and the release of painreducing chemicals.

The word placebo means I shall please in Latin, hinting at a history of placating troubled patients. Placebos had to mimic the real treatments in order to be convincing, so they took the form of sugar pills, waterfilled injections and even sham surgeries.

Grammar is a set of patterns for how words are put together to form phrases or clauses. Different languages have different patterns. In English, the subject normally comes first, followed by the verb, and then the object.

Americans today are the most politically polarized since the Civil War, making it nearly impossible to reach a broad consensus. The term 'refugee' was first used in the UN's 1951 Refugee Convention. It means someone who is unable to return to their home country because of wellfounded fears of being persecuted. Diethyl ether was the first common inhalational anesthetics. Inhalational anesthesia is usually supplemented with intravenous anesthesia. Common intravenous agents include sedatives, like propofol, which induce unconsciousness, and opioids, like fentanyl, which reduce pain.

Anesthesia is a form of pain control. It works by sending electrical signals through the nervous system. It can be used to control the heart, lungs, kidneys and other organs. It is also used to treat serious injuries, such as broken bones.

When Napolon Bonaparte took power, he allowed small businesses to use traditional measurements redefined in metric terms. The metric system remained standard for formal use, and it spread across the continent, along with France's borders. After Portugal and the Netherlands switched to metric voluntarily, other nations followed, with colonial empires spreading the system.

The metric system arose from a political revolution. The leaders of the French Revolution sought to completely transform society. The Academy of Sciences convened to reform the system of measurements. Old standards based on arbitrary authority or local traditions were replaced with mathematical and natural relationships.

Aristotle described three types of persuasive speech. Forensic, or judicial, rhetoric establishes facts and judgements about the past. Humans used to eat less sugar than we do now, but they still had cavities. They used to use flint and beeswax to fill in the holes in their teeth. Today, we use toothpastes and other methods to fill the holes.

The best way to avoid a cavity is still cutting down on sugar intake and practicing good oral hygiene. That includes regular tooth brushing, flossing, and avoiding sugary, starchy, and sticky foods that cling to your teeth between meals.

How to sort books using Bubble Sort. First, pick a random book and compare it to every other book. Then, divide the line by placing all the books that come before the partition on its left and all the ones that come after it on its right. This is called Insertion Sort. Unlike Bubble Sort, it usually doesn't require comparing every pair of books.

QuickSort is one of the most efficient strategies used by programmers today. Each round of partitioning requires about 1,280 comparisons. If your partitions are pretty balanced, dividing the books into 128 sublines of ten would take about seven rounds, or 8,960 seconds.

Exercise, a healthy diet, and weight loss all lower the risk of heart attacks. Doctors recommend exercising a few times a week, doing both aerobic activity and strength training. A hearthealthy diet is low in sugar and saturated fats, which are linked to heart disease.

Chocolate was invented in 1828 by Dutchman Coenraad van Houten. It was first used as a medicine for ailments, like upset stomachs. By the 20th century, chocolate was no longer an elite luxury but had become a treat for the public.

Charlotte should offer Eliza slightly more than nothing, one coin at a time. Daniel should propose to keep all the gold and Eliza's one vote would not be enough.

Each player gets one coin to give to the other. If there's a tie, the other player gets the other coin. The winner gets to give the other one to the next person in the line of succession. If the other person wins, the winner gets the remaining coin.

Ibuprofen blocks the production of compounds that help the body transmit pain signals. The body starts efficiently eliminating the drug, with the blood dose decreasing by half every two hours on average. Back in the liver, another small fraction of the total amount of the drug gets transformed into metabolites, which are eventually filtered out by the kidneys.

Children are the most difficult to dose because their bodies change so quickly. If the dose is too low, the drug won't do its job. The best way to get the right dose is to read the label and consult your doctor or pharmacist.

The effects of ibuprofen on the body can last for up to a week. The drug can cause damage to the liver, kidneys, and other parts of the body. It can also cause liver damage if the drug is not taken in the right way.

The tea trade was so lucrative that the world's fastest sailboat, the clipper ship, was born out of intense competition. Archaeological evidence suggests tea was first cultivated there as early as 6,000 years ago, or 1,500 years before the pharaohs built the Great Pyramids of Giza.

The first tea was eaten as a vegetable or cooked with grain porridge. After hundreds of years of variations to the preparation method, the standard became to heat tea, pack it into portable cakes, grind it into powder, and create a beverage called muo cha, or matcha.

Before World War II, manufacturers of ceramic dinnerware used uranium oxide in colored glazes. Lead was used to make white paint in the 4th century BCE. The pigment was then used to create the color orange. In 1898, it was discovered to be a carcinogen. It is thought to have been used in the painting of the American Civil War.

The Voynich manuscript is thought to have been written in the 14th century. It is written in an unknown language. Some believe it was written by a Renaissance scholar. Others believe it is written by an ancient tribe. It has been carbon dated to around 1420.

The Voynich manuscript is the only copy of a 240page book. It was written by a Polish Jesuit priest in the early 1800s. The book is written in a language that has never been seen before. It is thought to be written in the language of the 15thcentury.

Inventors have proposed plenty of ideas to keep a perpetual motion machine moving. Several of these have been variations on Bhaskara's overbalanced wheel with rolling balls or weights on swinging arms. None of them work because the parts that make one side of the wheel heavier also shift its center of mass downward below the axle.

The laws of thermodynamics have stymied every idea for a perpetual motion machine. Even if engineers could somehow design a machine that didn't violate the first law, it still wouldn't work in the real world. The one thing that seems truly perpetual is our search for new exotic forms of matter.

The first law of thermodynamics says that energy can't be created or destroyed. Around 1159 A.D., a mathematician called Bhaskara the Learned sketched a design for a wheel containing curved reservoirs of mercury. The idea was radical and helped to disprove the longstanding model of atoms.

Marie Curie was the first woman to win the Nobel Prize in physics. She was also the first person to discover the neutron star. She died in 1934 after suffering a heart attack in a car crash. Her work helped pave the way for the development of modern medicine.

Most cults share some basic characteristics. A typical cult requires a high level of commitment from its members. It maintains a strict hierarchy, separating unsuspecting supporters and recruits from the inner workings. It claims to provide answers to life's biggest questions through its doctrine, along with the required recipe for change.

Cults are skilled at knowing whom to target. They tend to be motivated by money, sex, or all three. The resulting internal conflict, known as cognitive dissonance, keeps you trapped. Many members eventually find a way out, whether through their own realizations or the help of family and friends.

A cult is a group or movement with a shared commitment to an extreme ideology. Not all cults are religious. Some are political, therapybased, focused on selfimprovement, or otherwise. The idea that the left side of the brain controls logic and the right, creativity, is a myth unsupported by scientific evidence. Some people may be particularly logical or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides of their brains. The idea of logic and creativity being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well.

The human brain is split into a left and right side. The left and the right sides of the brain do control different body functions. The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world. Every brain is different, which explains why people's experiences of concussions vary.

Subconcussive impacts can be hard to diagnose because the symptoms unfold slowly over time. Deep water fish don't reproduce until they're at least ten years old. This makes them vulnerable to overfishing when the young are caught before they've had the chance to spawn. Consumer taste and prices can also have harmful effects. Almost 31% of the world's fish populations are overfished.

Modern industrial fishing looks more like warfare. Radar, sonar, helicopters, and spotter planes are all used to guide factory ships towards dwindling schools of fish. Long lines with hundreds of hooks or huge nets round up massive amounts of fish, including seabirds, turtles, and dolphins.

Fishermen are using new technology to catch more fish. But they are also using it to make more mistakes. People who are not as good at something as they think they are are most likely to make mistakes. The problem is that we don't know how to fix it.

The DunningKruger effect isn't a question of ego blinding us to our weaknesses. People usually do admit their deficits once they can spot them. Experts tend to be aware of just how competent they are. But they often make a different mistake: they assume that everyone else is too.

Psychological research suggests that we're not very good at evaluating ourselves accurately. The more knowledgeable we become, the less likely we are to have invisible holes in our competence. The DunningKruger effect explains why more than 100 studies have shown that people display illusory superiority.

Choking is when a person fails to perform a task despite years of practice. Research suggests that some are more susceptible than others, especially those who are selfconscious, anxious, and afraid of being judged by others. It helps to practice under stressful conditions.

Choking is common in sports, where performance often occurs under intense pressure. Performance suffers when the mind is preoccupied with worries, doubts, or fears. Cervantes novel unfolds as a collection of episodes detailing the mishaps of the valiant knight. The book was so well received that readers clamored for more. After a rival author attempted to cash in on a fake followup, Cervantes released the official sequel in response.

Miguel de Cervantes' Don Quixote is the bestselling novel of all time. The tale follows the adventures of Alonso Quijano, known as the Knight of the Sorrowful Countenance. The novel has inspired art, literature, popular culture, and even political revolution.

The cortical homunculus is a model of the human body with proportions based on the size of each body parts representation in the cortex. The amount of cortex devoted  to a specific body part can grow or shrink based on how much sensory input the brain receives from that body part.

The accuracy of these apparitions suggests that we have a map of the body in our brains. The loss of a limb alters the way signals travel at every step of the pathway. We dont know why some amputees escape the pain typically associated with these phantoms.

Samuel Beckett's Waiting for Godot is considered a play that changed the face of modern drama. Written between 1949 and 1955, it offers a simple but stirring question  what should the characters do? Critics have offered countless readings of the play, resulting in a cycle of ambiguity and speculation.

Theatre of the Absurd is a movement which emerged after the Second World War. The characters wait in vain for an unknown figure to give them a sense of purpose. While they wait, they sink into boredom, express religious dread and contemplate suicide.

Gravity causes flames to expand and rise, which gives them their characteristic taper. Molecules emit light when heated, and the color of the light depends on the temperature of the molecules. Even the hottest fires run out of fuel or oxygen eventually.

Fire is not a plasma, the fourth state of matter in which atoms are stripped of their electrons. Instead, its our sensory experience of a chemical reaction called combustion. Time is a property that comes out of how the pieces are strung together. Emergent properties are things that dont exist in individual pieces of a system, but do exist for the system as a whole. Could time just be some sort of illusion generated by the limitations of the way we perceive the universe?

Einsteins theory seemed to confirm that time is woven into the very fabric of the universe. But why is it we can move through space in any direction, but through time in only one? Physicists are still exploring these and other questions, so were far from a complete explanation.

Ride designers are well aware of what your body, and the coaster, can handle. At 5 Gs, your body feels 5 times heavier; so if you weigh 100lbs, youd exert the weight of 500 lbs on the coaster. Modern rides are also much sturdier, closely considering the amount of gravity they need to withstand.

Ride coasters are propelled around their tracks almost entirely by gravitational energy. In the days of the FlipFlap, designers were most concerned with coasters getting stuck somewhere along the track. Today, coasters can pull off far more exciting tricks, without resorting to the thrill of a ride.

Gravity is generated by variations  in the curvature of spacetime. Traveling higher would make a bigger dent  in gravitys influence, but you wont escape it. Even safely tethered to the Earth, were subject to the faint tug of distant celestial bodies.

Gravity is the attractive force between two objects with mass. Every object in the universe attracts every other object. Every star, black hole, human being, smartphone, and atom are all constantly pulling on each other. So why dont we feel pulled in billions  of different directions?

Henry VIII embodied all the contradictions of monarchy on the verge of the modern era. But separating the ruler from the myth is all part of putting history on trial.

Henry VIII was a powerful king whose break with the church of Rome would forever change  the course of English history. He uprooted the countrys religious foundations and broke the Church of England away from Rome, leading to centuries of strife. The story of Sisyphus is one of repeated punishment. He was told to roll a boulder up a hill and then roll it down again. He refused to do it twice and was sent back to the top. The story has become a symbol of the futile search for meaning in life.

In 1968 physicists found that protons and neutrons are actually made of quarks, which are indivisible. A proton contains two up quarks  and one down quark. A neutron contains two down  quarks and one up. Why are there three (and only three) different versions of each of these particles?

The ATLAS Experiment on  the Large Hadron Collider is studying the Standard Model indepth. By taking precise measurements of the particles and forces that make up the universe, ATLAS physicists can look for answers to mysteries not explained by the Standard model.

The Standard Model explains how particles interact with each other. It also covers the forces that govern how particles move, interact, and bind together to give shape to the world around us. While the Standard Model provides a beautiful explanation, there are still a universes worth of mysteries left to explore.

The Intentional Fallacy states that an artist's intended meaning is the only possible interpretation. Shakespeare's A Midsummers Night's Dream sees the Bard get psychedelic. The trickster Puck sprinkles the juice of a magical flower over the eyes of the napping Demetrius and Lysander. The result is a night of chaos that includes broken hearts, mistaken identity, and transformations.

A Midsummer Night's Dream is one of Shakespeare's  friskiest works, filled with trickery, madness and magic. The moon overlooks the action like a silver bow, signifying erratic behavior. Killer whales are the main source of food for their families. Older females are more closely related to the family than younger females. This may be why they are more likely to die out in their thirties. They are also more able to raise their own children than other females.

As early as 8000 BCE, the earliest Neolithic farmers began a legacy of cheesemaking. Nomadic Mongolians used yaks milk to create hard, sundried wedges of Byaslag. The Greeks produced bricks of salty brined feta cheese, alongside a harder variety similar to  pecorino romano.

The discovery of cheese gave Neolithic people an enormous survival advantage. Milk was rich with essential proteins,  fats, and minerals. But it also contained high quantities of lactose  a sugar which is difficult to process. Cheese, however, could provide all of milks advantages with much less lactose. And since it could be preserved and stockpiled, these essential nutrients could be eaten throughout scarce famines and long winters.

One of the more fascinating examples of animal deception comes from the forktailed drongo. This bird sits atop tall trees in the Kalahari Desert, surveying the landscape for predators. Modern ECT is much safer than it used to be, but patients can still experience side effects. Most patients treated with ECT have two or three sessions per week for several weeks. ECT maintenance works better when paired with medication, even in patients who were resistant to medication before.

The treatment was first used in medicine in 1938. In its early years, doctors administered a strong electrical current to the brain, causing a wholebody seizure during which patients might bite their tongues or even break bones. Modern ECT is very different. While a patient is under  general anesthesia, electrodes deliver a series of mild electrical pulses to thebrain. This causes huge numbers of neurons to fire in unison: a brief, controlled seizure.

TED asked you to choose between a circle or a square. Your choice of circle meant flip the coin, and your choice of square was don't flip We received 372 responses. That means we can play 372 games against the quantum computer using your choices.

The key idea here is that we have to give up on precise values of zero and one and allow for some uncertainty. During the game, the quantum computer creates this fluid combination of heads and tails,zero and one. No matter what the player does, flip or no flip, the superposition remains intact.

Quantum uncertainty could be used to create private keys for encrypting messages sent from one location to another. It could also transform health care and medicine. The sloth is the world's slowest mammal. But like The Beatles, sloths are also extremely successful. They live in the jungles of Central and South America, and are extremely prolific. So what if, rather than deriding the sloth for being different, we tried to learn from it instead?

We idolize animals like the cheetah, the Ferrari of the animal kingdom The sloth, on the other hand, can reach a leisurely 17 feet a minute with the wind behind it. They survive by capturing and consuming static leaves.

Sloths have the slowest digestion rate of any mammal. They can take up to a month to process a single leaf. They do about 10 percent of the work of a similarsized mammal and survive on as little as 100 calories a day. They have more neck bones than any other mammal.

Sloths have long, hooked claws and a high fatigue resistance, so they can literally hook on and hang like a happy, hairy hammock for hours on end. Their throat and blood vessels are uniquely adapted to pump blood and to swallow food against the force of gravity. They have sticky bits on their ribs that prevent their enormous stomach from crushing their lungs.

Sloths are stealth ninjas, rarely leave the safety of the canopy, except to defecate. Their fur has grooves that attract moisture and act as tiny hydroponic gardens for algae. Their lack of muscle hasn't impeded their strength or agility.

Sloths are generally silent, solitary creatures, except for when the female is in heat. So the female remains covert, even when yodeling for sex at the top of her lungs. Her clandestine booty calls will carry for miles across the canopy, and males will beat a slow path towards her.

Sloths have been around on this planet in one shape or another for over 40 million years. The secret to their success is their slothful nature. They are energysaving icons. I founded the Sloth Appreciation Society to both promote and protect their slow, steady, sustainable lives.

Vultures can't see individual carcasses. But the sight of their fellow vultures guides them to the feeding. Their featherless heads help them regulate the sudden rise in temperature as they descend. The carcass is stripped clean in hours before the rotting meat infects the water supply.

conservationists have successfully banned drugs like Diclofenac. Researchers are working to repopulate vulture communities through breeding programs. Some regions have even opened vulture restaurants where farmers safely dispose of drugfree livestock. With help, vultures will be able  to continue their role conserving the health of our planet.

Two standing stones from the 10th century memorialize different generations of a royal family. The stones announce the power of this Viking Age dynasty. They indicate that Denmark was the earliest major Viking Age kingdom, by telling that Harald controlled southern Norway.

The Vikings left few monuments. Instead, fragments of stone,  bark, and bone provide the keys to their culture. Many of these objects are inscribed with messages in Old Norse. There was no standard spelling,  they wrote the individual runic letters by pronouncing the sounds of their regional accents.

Risk evaluation is a complicated tangle of statistical thinking and personal preference. Risk is the likelihood that an event will occur. Haircell damage is common: noise exposure, ordinary aging, illness. With a cochlear implant, computer chips do the job for the damaged hair cells. About five percent of the world has significant hearing loss. By 2050, that's expected to double to over 900 million people.

In silence, I see sound. When I watch a music video without sound, I can hear music. My mind is no longer competing with the distraction of sound. I'm hearing when I need to be, and the rest of the time, I'm not.

With the cochlear implant, I can stream music from my iPod into my head without earbuds. I once had a travel roommate who had a complete temper tantrum, because I didn't hear her knocking on the door when her key didn't work. I've never seen an episode of Star Trek.

tracking a spacecraft as it travels through deep space is fundamentally a problem of measuring time. Getting it wrong by just a tiny fraction of a second might mean the difference between your spacecraft safely and gently landing on the surface of another planet. Historically, we have been able to send smallish things extremely far away thanks to very large things here on our home planet.

Voyager 1 is just over 13 billion miles away right now. It takes a signal traveling at the speed of light over 40 hours to get there and back again. It would be great if we could measure that signal time directly at the spacecraft. But the miniaturization of atomic clock technology is difficult.

An ionbased atomic clock has the potential to completely flip the way we navigate in deep space. With this clock technology, we can now build GPSlike navigation systems at other planets and moons. Imagine having GPS on the Moon or Mars. Imagine in this scenario that we can have a network of communication satellites scattered throughout deep space broadcasting navigation signals.

autonomy means we can support more spacecraft, more sensors to explore the universe, and it also frees up navigators to work on finding the answers to other questions. In 2013, the Denver Post won a Pulitzer Prize for covering the Aurora theater shooting. The paper that once had 300 journalists would now have 70. Since 2004, nearly 1,800 newsrooms have closed in the U.S., the Post says.

The story of a man who became a famous doctor. The doctor was summoned to treat the king when he fell ill. But when he entered the kings chamber, he was dismayed to see Death at the foot of the bed. He swiftly spun the bed around, leaving the doctor free to administer the antidote.

The story of a man who lost his life in a forest. The man's dying wish was to cure his daughter of her illness. But when he tried to do so, he found himself surrounded by Death. He was forced to give up his wish and die.

The Second Sex by Simone de Beauvoir is published by Simon & Schuster, priced 16.99. The book explores the role of women in a maledominated society. The author argues that women should be free to choose their own role in society.

The Second Sex was written by French philosopher Simone de Beauvoir. The book was a landmark in the field of feminist theory. The author was accused of sexual misconduct by two of her students. She died in 1986 at the age of 80.

In 1941, de Beauvoir published  the first of three books on the ocean, combining science with lyrical meditations on underwater worlds. She argued that our greatest ethical imperative is to create our own lifes meaning, while protecting the freedom of others to do the same.

Silent Spring was published in 1962. Rachel Carson's work galvanized a generation of environmental activists. Carson died of cancer in 1964, only two years after the book's publication. In 1972, the EPA issued a partial ban on the use of DDT.

Carson was the second woman to be hired at the Bureau of Fisheries. She and her friends started the Sierra Leone War Trust for Children. They helped single mothers with children under the age of five. The Trust is still helping the women and children of Sierra Leone.

Benjamin Franklin invented what he called double spectacles These have lenses with a single focal power tuned so that near objects come into focus. Today we also have progressive lenses which get rid of the line by smoothly varying the focal power from top to bottom.

The part of the eye that allows us to refocus to different distances is called the crystalline lens. The muscles surrounding the lens can deform it into different shapes, which in turn changes its focusing power. The last several decades have seen the creation and rapid development of what are called focustunable lenses

Stanford researchers have developed an autofocals prototype. It uses technology from virtual and augmented reality systems to estimate focusing distance. The prototype was tested on 100 presbyopia sufferers and they found it easier and better focusing than their current correction.

phthalmologist Leslie Gauthier says autofocals don't compromise like static corrections in use today do. He says the focustunable lens technology is capable of outperforming traditional forms of static correction. It's pretty clear that in the near future, instead of worrying about which pair of glasses to use, we'll be able to just focus on the important things, he says.

Opioid drugs act on the bodys opioid system by binding to receptors in the brain. When a drug binds to opioid receptors, it triggers the release of dopamine. dopamine is linked to feelings of pleasure and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria that characterizes an opioid high.

The body compensates by increasing  its number of noradrenaline receptors. This increased sensitivity allows the body to continue functioning normally. When someone who is physically dependent on opioids stops taking them abruptly, that balance is disrupted. This oversensitivity causes muscle aches, stomach pains, fever, and vomiting.

Opioid addiction is rarely a standalone illness; frequently, people with opioid dependence are also struggling with a mental health condition. A drug called naloxone is currently  our best defense against overdose. There are both inpatient  and outpatient programs that combine medication, health services,  and psychotherapy.

In the 1980s and 90s, pharmaceutical companies began  to market opioid painkillers aggressively. More than 3,000 years ago, a flower began to appear in remedies in Ancient Egyptian medical texts. The number of opioid painkiller prescriptions skyrocketed and so did cases of opioid addiction.

Coronaviruses have a slower mutation rate than other RNA viruses. This means our immune systems, drugs, and vaccines might be able to recognize them for longer after infection, and therefore protect us better. The virus in question was a coronavirus that caused an epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS.

There are hundreds of known coronaviruses. Seven of them infect humans, and can cause disease. Four cause colds, mild, highly contagious infections of the nose and throat. Two infect the lungs, and cause much more severe illnesses. The seventh, which causes COVID19, has features of each.

Primers are used to identify the virus. Immunoassays tap into the immune systems memory of the virus, showing if someone has previously been infected. The presence of IgM antibodies suggests a recent infection, but theyre unreliable in diagnosing current infections.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared a pandemic, meaning that its spreading worldwide. The idea here is to simultaneously starve the virus, everywhere, through a combination of quarantine, social distancing, and restricting travel. Racing through it is a quick fix,  but would be a global catastrophe.

Vaccination, assisted by as much global coordination as possible, is generally considered to be the winner. The WHO will likely declare  the pandemic over once the infection is mostly contained. Breakthroughs in treatment  and prevention of symptoms can make viruses much less dangerous, and therefore require less extreme containment measures.

In times like these, theres an urgent need for a vaccine to create widespread immunity with minimal loss of life. Inactivated vaccines take a much faster approach, directly applying heat, acid, or radiation to weaken the pathogen. Subunit vaccines, that inject  harmless fragments of viral proteins, can also be created quickly.

Vaccine development can generally be split into three phases. In exploratory research, scientists experiment with different approaches to find safe and replicable vaccine designs. In clinical testing, vaccines are evaluated for safety, efficacy, and side effects. Finally, theres manufacturing, where vaccines are produced and distributed for public use.
